q: What are leg cramps?
a: Leg cramps happen when a muscle in the leg tightens and causes a sudden pain that can make it hard to move. The cramps can last from a few seconds to 10 minutes.

q: What are the possible causes of leg cramps?
a: Leg cramps can be caused by aging, putting too much strain on muscles during exercise, pregnancy, certain medications, dehydration, and liver disease.

q: What can I do during a leg cramp?
a: During a cramp, stretching and massaging the muscle may ease the pain.

q: How can I prevent leg cramps?
a: Regular calf-stretching exercises may help to reduce cramps.

q: Do painkillers help with leg cramps?
a: Paracetamol or ibuprofen can help to ease muscle soreness after a cramp, but they will not help when it's happening as they take too long to work.

q: When should I see a doctor about leg cramps?
a: You should see a GP if leg cramps are disturbing your sleep, you also have numbness or swelling in your legs, or if the cramps last longer than 10 minutes.

q: What can a GP do to treat leg cramps?
a: A GP will examine you to try to find out the reason for your leg cramps and suggest a treatment depending on the cause, which might include stretching exercises or quinine tablets if exercise has not helped.

q: Are quinine tablets safe for treating leg cramps?
a: Quinine tablets are not suitable for everyone, and the GP will discuss potential risks and side effects with you.

q: How can I stretch my calf muscles to reduce leg cramps?
a: Stand facing a wall and stretch out your arms until your hands can just touch it. Lean forward, pressing your hands against the wall until you feel your calf muscles stretch. Repeat this exercise for a few times, 5 minutes, 3 times a day.

q: What are the common symptoms of leg cramps?
a: Common symptoms of leg cramps include sudden pain in the leg, difficulty in moving the leg, and muscle soreness after the cramp has stopped.

q: Is quinine a suitable treatment for leg cramps?
a: Quinine tablets can be used as a treatment for leg cramps if other methods haven't helped. However, they are not suitable for everyone, and the GP will discuss potential risks and side effects with you.

q: What are some known causes of leg cramps?
a: Some known causes of leg cramps include aging, overexertion of muscles during exercise, pregnancy, certain medications like statins or diuretics, dehydration, and liver disease due to excessive alcohol consumption.

q: What are leg cramps?
a: Leg cramps happen when a muscle in the leg tightens and causes a sudden pain that can make it hard to move. The cramps can last from a few seconds to 10 minutes. They can affect the calf muscle, below the knee at the back of the leg, or muscles in the feet or thighs less often. After the cramp has stopped, the muscle might feel sore for up to 24 hours.

a: During a leg cramp, stretching and massaging the muscle may ease the pain, although most cramps go away without you doing anything. Paracetamol or ibuprofen can help to ease muscle soreness after a cramp, but they will not help when it's happening as they take too long to work.
